bibl.title: Report: Yellow Fever in Guayaquil, by Henry Rose Carter, July 20, 1916

div1.p: Carter discusses needed mosquito-control work in Guayaquil and the endemic focus of yellow fever. He believes that the local population will cooperate, and so work should proceed. The city should be provided with a proper water supply to ensure continued success of the work.

div1.head: Report: Yellow Fever in Guayaquil, by Henry Rose Carter, July 20, 1916
div1.opener:
Report
on
YELLOW FEVER
in
Guayaquil.
-----------o------------
Submitted by Dr. H.R. Carter.
----o----
July 20, 1916.
Aboard Steamship “Ucayali”,
July 20, 1916.
General Wm. C. Gorgas.
Chairman, Yellow Fever Commission,
Rockefeller Foundation.
Sir:
div1.p:
I have the honor to submit the following report on the
yellow fever situation in Guayaquil:

Status of
Guayaquil.

Yellow fever prevails in Guayaquil endemically. This
condition has existed, in all probability for, say - from
thirty-five to forty-five years, during which time it has been
always present in Guayaquil. This place is, then, and has been
for many years an endemic focus of yellow fever.

Infection of
other towns
from Guaya-
quil.

Yellow fever has, from time to time, been introduced
from Guayaquil into a number of small towns in communi-
cation with it and, where local conditions in such towns
were suitable, they have become infected with that disease. This
is especially true of those on the line of the Guayaquil & Quito
Railroad up to and including Bucay. At Huigra, at four thousand
feet elevation, yellow fever has not spread, although it has been
introduced quite frequently. The same infection has almost cer-
tainly occurred in the coast towns of Ecuador. The communication
between Guayaquil and these towns has been such that it is entirely
crediable that Guayaquil should have been a source of infection to
all of these towns and to Tumaco and Buenaventura in Colombia, as
well. The latter of these towns was infected in 1915, as was
Esmeraldas, in Ecuador. Epidemics of yellow fever in the coast
towns of Peru and Chile have, in times past, also been attributed
to Guayaquil and a recent sharp epidemic in the latter country seems
clearly from this source.
(Yellow Fever situation in Guayaquil,- Carter)

Status of
these towns.

The towns on the railroad and on the coast of Ecuador
are, it is believed, small enough to clear themselves
of yellow fever spontaneously if not re-infected from Guayaquil.
Indeed, they seem to have done so at times in the past. Even if
this be not true a very small amount of work should be sufficient
to free them of yellow fever if further introduction from Guayaquil
be stopped.

Whether Buenaventura (Keane gives it 6,000 inhabitants in 1909),
would free itself of yellow fever without sanitary work, may be a
question. I am inclined to think that it would. If not, only a
small amount of work for mosquito-control should be required to so
free it.

It is to be noted that the towns on the railroad and the ad-
jacent haciendas, which are really small towns, are growing rapidly,
and if Guayaquil remains infected some years longer they may, in the
aggregate, be large enough to require sanitary work to free them of
yellow fever. I say in the aggregate as the inter-communication
between them is close enough for one to be a source of infection to
the others.

Continued in-
fection de-
pendent on
Guayaquil.

It is believed, then, that if Guayaquil is freed from
the infection of yellow fever the remaining towns on the
Pacific coast of South America will either spontaneously
free themselves by a failure of the human host or, at most, only a
small amount of work would be required and at a very few places to
accomplish this result.

Advisability
of sanitation
of Guayaquil.

I regard Guayaquil then, as the key of the yellow fever
situation ofn the Pacific coast of South America.
(Yellow Fever situation in Guayaquil; Carter)

The trade relations of this part of the coast are such that,
once free of yellow fever there is a minimum chance of its re-
infection from other existing foci. I consider then, the elimina-
tion of yellow fever from Guayaquil as extremely advisable and need
only consider its feasibility.

Feasi-
bility.

For this the two main factors to consider are (1), the atti-
tude of the authorities and the people of the place at which
sanitary work is proposed toward such work, and (2), the natural diffi-
culties to be overcome.

Support of
authorities.

The proposition to eliminate yellow fever from Guayaquil
meets with the cordial approval of the authorities of both
that city and of the Republic, and of all such business men and
physicians as we have seen. The attempt to do so along the lines
outlined to them will receive their support and, if sufficient care
and tact be used can, I believe, be carried out with little opposi-
tion from any source.

Natural diffi-
culties; water
supply.

It seems then, that we need only consider the natural
difficulties of the work to be overcome. Of these the
only one worth mentioning is the insufficient water supply. Since
the method mainly relied upon is the control of mosquitos (Aëdes
calopus), by the destruction of their breeding places and since the
insufficiency of the present water supply necessitates the purchase
and storage of water for domestic purposes in artificial containers
in which water such mosquitos breed, it is obvious that if a suffi-
cient supply of water were procurable and was properly distributed so
as to do away with the necessity of water-storage, the work would be
4.
(Yellow Fever situation in Guayaquil; Carter)
much simplified. If this can be done the task becomes easy and
success certain. This matter will be presented to the Foundation
in a special communication by the Chairman of this Commission; but
I cannot too strongly present the advisability of providing a suffi-
cient and properly distributed water supply as an adjuvant, possibly
a prerequisite, to the work proposed.

This can be done within eighteen months if funds be available,
but under the arrangements which obtain at present will take decidedly
longer.

Advisable to
begin work as
soon as prac-
ticable.

It is deemed advisable, however, not to postpone the
work for the elimination of yellow fever on this account
but to begin it as soon as practicable. By the method
purposed to be adopted the work will probably take considerable time
as it is deemed advisable to proceed carefully so as to arouse no
opposition to our sanitary measures. A disadvantage in waiting any
considerable time would be that we would not then find (unless indeed
the Foundation should undertake the introduction of water) the same
willingness of the authorities and people to cooperate with us as at
present exists.

It is believed that the work of mosquito control can be success-
fully carried out now with the present water supply. It will be more
difficult than if the supply were sufficient and properly distributed.
It will take longer and require much care and tact to bring it to a
successful issue. Given the care and tact, however, I believe it can
be done.

Conditions
favoring work
at present.

Indeed, Guayaquil is, just now, better suited for work
of this kind to be successful than is normally the case
with that city. The existence of the present epidemic will make the
(Yellow Fever situation in Guayaquil; Carter)
5
civic authorities more anxious to have the work done and increase
the cooperation of all classes with us. The considerable number
of susceptible people it will immunize before it stops will raise
the level of the “critical number” of mosquitos (Aëdes calopus) al-
lowable with the elimination of yellow fever. The temporary les-
sening of the Serrano immigration due to the knowledge of this epi-
demic, a fairly fatal one, will have the same effect.

There is one other point favorable for this work in Guayaquil,
namely, the long, dry, cool, season, lasting about eight months.
Aëdes calopus were certainly not breeding at all freely during our
stay. The temperature was about 65 to 70 degrees, F., and there
is probably normally no very free production of this mosquito during
the dry season. During this part of the year, then, the climatic
conditions are favorable for success.

If the attempt to eliminate yellow fever should fail to do so
prior to the introduction of a sufficient and properly distributed
water supply it would at least control the disease during this time,
and after a proper water supply is introduced a continuation of the
attempt would of course have a better chance of success.
